label: forensics
definition_with_punc: The art or study of argumentation and formal debate.

label: forsci
definition_with_punc: Any science used for the purposes of the law.

label: rstats
definition_with_punc: R is a free software environment for statistical computing and graphics.
source_display: The R Project for Statistical Computing

label: ide
definition_with_punc: An IDE increases programmer productivity by combining common activities of writing software into a single application: editing source code, building executables, and debugging.

label: openss
definition_with_punc: Open source software is software with source code that anyone can inspect, modify, and enhance.

label: sourcecode
definition_with_punc: The part of software that most computer users don't ever see; it's the code computer programmers can manipulate to change how a piece of software—a "program" or "application"—works.

label: evidence
definition_with_punc: Data presented to a court or jury in proof of the facts in issue and which may include the testimony of witnesses, records, documents, or objects.

label: score
definition_with_punc: The quanitification of similarity between two items via a univariate function meant to inform whether the two items have a common source.

label: lr
definition_with_punc: Statistical measurement evaluating the probability of evidence under one hypotheis, divided by the probability of evidence under an alternative, mutually exclusive hypothesis. In forensic science, the value of the likelihood ratio expresses the weight and meaning of scientific evidence and is used as a measure of probative value.

label: dnaprof
definition_with_punc: A method of identifying an individual through comparison of patterns arising from differences in DNA sequences, represented as a string of values compiles from the results of DNA testings at one or more genetic markers.

label: pcr
definition_with_punc: An *in vitro* process that yields millions of copies of desired DNA through repeated cycling of a reaction involving the DNA polymerase enzyme.

label: str
definition_with_punc: Multiple copies of an identical DNA sequence arranged in direct succession where the repeat  sequence unit is 2 to 6 base pairs in length.

label: snp
definition_with_punc: Any polymorphic variation at a single nucleotide.

label: mtdna
definition_with_punc: A small, circular DNA molecule located in the mitocondria that contains approximately 16,500 nucleotides. The abundance of hundreds of copies of mtDNA in each cell make it useful with samples originating from limited or damaged biological material.

label: chromo
definition_with_punc: The structure by which hereditary information is physically transmitted from one generation to the next.

label: locus
definition_with_punc: A unique physical location of a gene (or specific sequence of DNA) on a chromosome. The plural of locus is loci.

label: nucleotide
definition_with_punc: A unit of nucleic acid composed of phospate, ribose or deoxyribose, and a purine or pyrimidine base

label: nucleicacid
definition_with_punc: A general class of molecules that are polymers of nucleotides. DNA and RNA are the major types.

label: ce
definition_with_punc: An electrophoretic technique for separating DNA molecules by their size based on migration through a narrow glass capillary tube filled with a liquid polymer.

label: allele
definition_with_punc: An alternative form of a gene or a section of DNA at a particluar gentic location (locus). Typically, multiple alleles are possible for each STR marker.

label: stutter
definition_with_punc: Either (n-4) or (n+4). If (n-4), a minor peak appearing one repeat unit smapper than a primary STR allele resulting from strang slippage during the amplification process. If (n+4), a minor peak appearing one repeat unit larger than a primary STR allele resulting from strand slippage during the amplification process.

label: gui
definition_with_punc: A form of user interface that allows users to interact with electronic devices through graphical icons and visual indicators such as secondary notation, instead of text-based user interfaces.
